review.abstract: Summit work of the Spanish Golden Age and forefather of the so-called picaresque novel, The Life of Lazarillo de Tormes and of His Fortunes and Adversities still remains an anonymous text. As in a state-of-the-art survey, we discuss the methods used and how they perform in our specific case. sections.heading: Discussion
sections.text: According to the statistical approach of Madrigal, Juan Arce Otálora has been consistently assigned high positions in the analysis of the authorship of Lazarillo, but if we want to accept the result of Burrows's delta and Koppel and Schler debunking method, the evidence is not enough to support him as the true author: both methods agree on the prominent similarity between Arce de Otálora and Alfonso de Valdés "writing style, but suggest that one of them is indeed the author. However, we add that the candidacy for Arce de Otálora was strongly supported. Deficiencies are generally due to the corpus rather than the methodology. Diego Hurtado de Mendoza, on the other hand, is one of the most documented candidates of all, and possibly the one we trust who has not proved to be a strong player in our analysis.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text: This study began with an overview of the status of the question of authorship of the Lazarillo mask, which enabled us to establish a base corpus of candidates with whom to work. Subsequent exploratory analysis, using distance-based metrics and methods from unattended learning, gave the first clues. Juan Arce de Otálora and Alfonso de Valdés were then highlighted and soon supported by the use of more sophisticated methods.The majority of the statistical evidence seems to point towards Arce de Otálora with greater distance in relation to Valdés, and while our corpus is not as comprehensive as that used by Madrigal, the legal scholar is still selected by the learning methods as the most likely author. It seems as if all statistical techniques agree with Arce de Otálora authors who support the Madrigal hypothesis, but it may not be the ultimate proof that the author needs authority.

sections.heading: Further Research
sections.text: Much remains to be done in terms of computer-aided approaches to resolving the anonymity of Lazarillo. In addition, forensic linguistics also includes issues related to the author plagiarism and author clustering, which could help, for example, to identify the legitimacy of interpolaciones as part of Lazarillo's text, or to identify whether differences intervened in the creation of the small book. However, debates in this context can also be enriched by the use of modern techniques such as that of social network analysis. Previous studies in various areas have proved useful in order to shed some light on the discussion of similar issues and contribute to investigating the graph structure of the actors involved (Suárez, Sancho, and de la Rosa).
